review_blob: This was called Brigand Winter where I got it, and poured a pale amber colour with a soft, white head that dissipated leaving white lacing. Aroma is hoppy, sour, citrus, while the taste is similar with coriander and malt. It leaves a strange almost metallic aftertaste.

Red-brown colour, thick almost beige head that lasts, leaving thin lacing. Interesting tastes that are hard to define, liquorice, coriander, strawberry were initial tastes, but there is definitely something more to this beer. Leaves a malty, coriander aftertaste

Shiny golden Kasteel tripel, with a thick, firm, pillowy head that lasts, leaving light lacing. A mild beginning, with a sudden explosion of sharp, fruity taste that warms and softens to vanilla, citrus and cognac, from the barrels it was matured in. A unique taste that is well worth investigating.

beer_brewer_name: Brouwerij der Trappistenabdij De Achelse Kluis
review_blob: Pours a cloudy red-brown with a thin head tat dissipates quickly. Very light in the mouth and smooth to drink. Initially tastes of figs, raisins, dandelion & burdock (weird), then mellows to trace elements of strawberries, caramel and a sweet liquorice taste, that stays with you.

Almost reminds me of warm treacle pie. Aroma is indistinct herbs and alcohol. With a short lived foamy head that leaves no lacing.

A mild, warming menthol taste, with caramel, treacle, liquorice and indistinct herbs. Very smooth in the mouth. This leaves a warm, herb and menthol aftertaste.

Pours an opaque red brown. Smells of malt, spices, only slightly fruity. Tastes very spicy, the coriander is quite overwhelming, the oranges seem to be an afterthought. Its dry and slightly sour, and leaves a spicy, dry aftertaste. Not too bad for an 8.5%, but I expected better.

A bit disappointing actually. The aroma is yeasty but with undertones of strawberry. The taste itself is mildly bitter, malty with strawberries hidden in its depths. The strawberry taste lingers in the aftertaste. It certainly doesnt taste like a 9% ABV, but it is easy to drink and goes down quickly.

Pours a soft brown with a voluminous pillowy head that slowly fades to leave a light lacing. The aroma is alcohol and spices with roasted malt and can be quite intense at first. Taste is roasted malt, spices, alcohol, cherries, prunes, raisins, some strawberry tones, slight vanilla, wood. Youd think this was barrel aged from the taste. Leaves a sharp alcohol, cherry and wood aftertaste.

This pours dark brown with a big mocha-coloured frothy head that lasts. It smells of singed malt and yeast and has a balanced taste of spicy sweetness and bitter hops, you can vaguely taste madeira in its depths and in the aftertaste, which is mostly of roasted malt and bitter hops.

This is the best chocolate beer Ive had. Rich chocolate brown colour with a pale brown almost velvety head that lasts and leaves snowflake lacing. Luxuriously smooth in your mouth, it tastes as rich as it smells. Very strong bitter coffee and chocolate taste with caramel, vanilla, toasted bread, liquorice and roasted malt tones. Surprisingly light on the palate for a strong tasting beer and the initial aftertaste of chocolate and bitter coffee fades to honey and caramel.

Pale amber colour, very little head, what there was dissipated quickly, leaves no lacing. Aroma is hops and vanilla, with some fruit. Taste is light, fruity - hints of lemon, grapefruit, mildly hoppy.. not sharp or bitter. Leaves a mild spicy aftertaste.

Clear dark chocolate brown colour with a creamy pale head that laces down the glass. Surprisingly fruity for a caramel, chocolate and malt dark beer. Smooth and light on the tongue, with a herb and dark malt aftertaste. Far lighter than you would think an 8.5 vol. would be.

Pours dark golden with a pale foamy head that dissipates quickly. Not a lot of lacing. It smells of malt and herbs, hiding a sudden bitter Orange-y taste that is quite pleasing and lasts, with a spiced orange, dry aftertaste.

Pours a rich but clear dark red, smells of alcohol, with hints of vanilla. Tastes sharply of the sherry barrels it was aged in, with dark fruits, bitter almond, caramel, oak wood and a nutty undertone. It leaves a bitter fruity almond aftertaste.
beer_name: La Trappe Quadrupel Oak Aged Batch #15

review_blob: Pours slightly cloudy golden with a pale foamy head. Aroma is hops, citrus, ginger. Tastes light and refreshing, smooth and hoppy with hints of citrus and a light spiciness.

Deep red/brown colour, with an off white foamy head that dissipates slowly, leaving white lacing. Aroma is caramel, red fruit, roasted malt, herbs, spices, earthy wood and some chocolate. Taste is similar with a light sour cherry, wood smoke, sweet vanilla and raisin. Aftertaste finds raspberry and strawberry tones.

Peaches, peaches and more peaches. Peach in colour, aroma, taste and aftertaste with a hoppy bitterness. Full bodied, sweet and refreshing. Not just a dessert beer though, would go very well with chicken and beef dishes.

Rich orange colour with a thick, dense, foamy head that leaves thick white lacing down the glass. Sharp orangey, grapefruit aroma. Orange, citrus, grapefruit, vanilla, butterscotch, cinnamon taste and aftertaste.

A new favourite.

Deep red with a pinkish head. Strong cherry aroma with hints of vanilla and wood. Sharp cherry tartness, almost jam-like, with hints of nut and roasted barley. Acidic cherry aftertaste with a nutty spiciness.
Creamy amber colour with a thick head of foam, smells and tastes of caramel and bitter hops with hints of banana. Leaves a bitter hoppy aftertaste.

Rich amber/red colour with a thin foamy head that fades rapidly, leaving white thick lacing on the glass. Aroma of spring flowers, apples, oranges and caramel that come through in the taste with honey and burnt sugar backed up with a peppery spice that lasts.

Pours dark amber with a thin foamy head that fades fast. Aroma is caramel, apple, pear and yeast. Smooth drinking with tones of buttered toast, toffee, pear with apple and malt underneath. Aftertaste is malt and caramel.

Pale copper poured, with a short-lived pale foamy head. Aroma is thyme and fruit, slightly sour. Vanilla, banana, apricot, thyme and coriander mix well for a surprisingly different taste with a smooth, clean, slightly spiced finish.
The perfect autumnal beer. Amber/red with a pale foamy head. Smooth liquorice with hints of apricot and a lightly smoked taste, followed by slightly bitter hops and a dry, but refreshing aftertaste.

Dark golden colour, with short lived pale head. Smooth malt, honey and coriander taste with hints of orange and lime. Sharp, spicy citrus and coriander aftertaste, soothed by the honey, lingering aftertaste.

Pours like sunshine, with a creamy head, aroma is sour barley, hop and yeast. It tastes of wheat and barley with vanilla and a sharp lemon twist, although its smooth and creamy in the mouth, leaving a sour wheat, yeast and bitter banana (?) aftertaste.

Clear ruby red colour with a pale off white head. Aroma is malty and sharp and sour. Has a robust taste of roasted malt, hops and caramel that is sharp and bitter. Leaves a bitter but refreshing aftertaste.
Dark amber colour, smooth creamy texture, sour, hop taste, with caramel, malt and toffee undertones. Tapped at the Angel Hotel at Catterick Village.
Pale honey colour, with a white head that lasts. Sweet, malty, refreshing taste. Not too bad, not what I expected.

Rich dark ruby colour, with a thick pale brown, foamy head. Aroma is sour, of hops and spices. Taste is sharp, but sweet and smooth, of coffee, spices and fruit. It definitely holds the taste of the Pauillac barrels, leaving a sharp, spicy, fruity, coffee tang.
beer_name: Van Den Bossche Buffalo Grand Cru (Barrel Aged Pauillac)

review_blob: Pours ruby, chestnut colour, with a beige foamy head. Aroma is spicy, slightly sour, almost rustic. It tastes of red berries, spices and wood, and is smooth and softer than you would expect from an 11% ale. The aftertaste is long lasting, of spices, wood and roasted hazelnuts (?). There is some carbonation that leaves you feeling a little bloated,

Opaque black in colour, Holds a strong yeast, malt, coffee aroma. It tastes much as it smells, strongly of yeast and roasted coffee and has a strong whiskey foretaste that turns bitter. The aftertaste is sharply whiskey, with a smokey/roasted bitterness that is over-powering and long lasting. Definitely one for the more discerning Stout drinker.
beer_name: Emelisse White Label Coffee Stout (Bruichladdich BA)

review_blob: Deep black colour with a chocolate brown foamy head. Smells strongly of burnt coffee, softened with chocolate, caramel and a spicy tinge. The taste is very soft considering the bitter coffee, chocolate, caramel, wood smoke and spices that all erupt in your mouth, leaving a sharp, bitter chocolate and spiced aftertaste. Its in my Top 10.

White Oak IPA. Cloudy gold colour, with a pale head that disperses quickly. Accents of grapefruit, lemon, melon, spring flowers and wheat make up the aroma. And are easily identifiable in the taste. It is light, fresh and summery and leaves a slightly sour, dry aftertaste.

Dark chocolate-y brown in colour, with a pale head that lasts. It has a roasted coffee aroma and a sweet, rich, full bodied taste that combines chocolate and coffee with a spiced bitterness, that stays with you. Having only ever had Leffe blond, this was a surprising gem to find, and I shall be making sure I have it again.

A lovely ruby body with a pale beige head, this Belgian Abbey beer smells quite strongly of barley and brown sugar with an underlying aroma of caramel and berry fruits. Its taste is surprising, as it is quite sweet and smoky flavoured, with a hint of cinnamon among the fruit. It leaves a cinnamon after taste.

Pours a dark chestnut red brown, with a beige head that lasts only seconds before wisping across the top of the beer. Aroma is heavily yeast and slightly burnt caramel. Thankfully it tastes rich and smooth, of caramel, brown sugar, malt and yeast. Leaving a malty taste on your palate.

Dark caramel in colour with an off-white head. This is a Dubbel style beer with a malty, peppery honey aroma. The taste is not as creamy or robust as the 8 or 10, but it still holds its own with caramel, brown sugar, honey and vanilla mixed with the toasted malt and spices. There is very little aftertaste, but it leaves a carbonated warmth on your palate.

Rich dark brown colour with a beige head. Smells of roasted coffee, caramel and malted chocolate (think Horlicks). It has an eclectic taste of malt, fruit, chocolate, hops, and coffee. It is both sweet and bitter and leaves a lengthy taste of bitter mocha in your mouth.

A shimmering gold colour with a pale yellow head. The aroma is sharp and citrusy, giving you the expectation of a similar taste and it doesnt disappoint. It is smooth on the tongue, sharp and slightly bitter, but citrusy and fresh, leaving a refreshing, clean feel.
beer_name: Rogue Nation Brutal India Pale Ale

review_blob: Strong cherry aroma when poured, flawless opaque red colour with a pale pink head. While the sweet cherry flavour fills your mouth, the undertones of malt and chocolate keep the sweetness from becoming tart and remind you of the Donker. The peppery aftertaste is both pleasant and refreshing.

Pours a deep chestnut red with a foamy beige head. Aroma is old oak and red berries, with a sharp sour smell. It tastes of malt, sour fruits, herbs and like a forest after a storm, earthy and woody, but robustly rather than bitterly and is smooth but tingly on your tongue. A very enjoyable beer for the more discerning palate.
